name: Stephen Melczer
content: Stephen Melczer Search Office - MC 6028 smelczer (at) uwaterloo.ca 1-519-888-4567 x41282 I’m an associate professor in the Department of Combinatorics and Optimization at the University of Waterloo (with a cross-appointment in the School of Computer Science), interested in leveraging computational algebraic geometry, analysis, and topology to create effective tools for combinatorics, computer science, and mathematics. An overview of some of my research interests can be found in the first chapter of An Invitation to Enumeration or the slides of my recent talk at FPSAC 2025. More details can be found on my research page. Previously I was a CRM-ISM postdoctoral fellow at UQAM (2019 – 2020) and a postdoc at the University of Pennsylvania (2017 – 2019). I received doctorates from the École normale supérieure de Lyon and the University of Waterloo in 2017. As of September 1, 2025 I am the associate chair for undergraduate studies in C&O. For advising during the F25 term, you can email questions to coundergrad.officer@uwaterloo.ca (do not send advising questions to my personal email) or book a virtual appointment on Thursday or Friday afternoon through this link. Virtual meetings use Microsoft Teams – please make sure Teams is installed and updated to the latest version before the start of our call. I’ve written a set of lecture notes and two textbooks, An Invitation to Enumeration (online lecture notes). An elementary introduction to enumerative combinatorics for math undergrads working up to the basics of analytic combinatorics. An Invitation to Analytic Combinatorics: From One to Several Variables (Springer). A gentle introduction to analytic combinatorics and analytic combinatorics in several variables (ACSV), focused on explicit computational methods. Analytic Combinatorics in Several Variables, 2nd Edition (Cambridge, with R. Pemantle and M. C. Wilson). The most complete and expansive treatment of ACSV, making use of topological methods to present a comprehensive framework for studying multivariate generating functions. These references give a pathway from first year university mathematics to the frontiers of research in analytic combinatorics. You should also try our sage_acsv package that will rigorously do (much of it) for you – feedback always welcome!
